001package squidpony.squidgrid.mapping;
002
003import squidpony.squidai.DijkstraMap;
004import squidpony.squidgrid.FOV;
005import squidpony.squidmath.Coord;
006import squidpony.squidmath.CoordPacker;
007import squidpony.squidmath.GreasedRegion;
008import squidpony.squidmath.IRNG;
009import squidpony.squidmath.IStatefulRNG;
010import squidpony.squidmath.OrthoLine;
011import squidpony.squidmath.StatefulRNG;

013import java.util.ArrayList;
014import java.util.Arrays;
015import java.util.List;
016import java.util.Map;
017import java.util.Set;

019/**
020 * A static class that can be used to modify the char[][] dungeons that other generators produce.
021 * Includes various utilities for random floor-finding, but also provides ways to take dungeons that use '#'
022 * for walls and make a copy that uses unicode box drawing characters.
023 *
024 * @author Tommy Ettinger - https://github.com/tommyettinger
025 * @see DungeonGenerator DungeonGenerator uses this class a fair amount
026 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 4/1/2015.
027 */
028public class DungeonUtility {
029
030    /**
031     * Constant for environment tiles that are not near a cave, room, or corridor. Value is 0.
032     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
033     */
034    public static final int UNTOUCHED = 0;
035    /**
036     * Constant for environment tiles that are floors for a room. Value is 1.
037     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
038     */
039    public static final int ROOM_FLOOR = 1;
040    /**
041     * Constant for environment tiles that are walls near a room. Value is 2.
042     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
043     */
044    public static final int ROOM_WALL = 2;
045    /**
046     * Constant for environment tiles that are floors for a cave. Value is 3.
047     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
048     */
049    public static final int CAVE_FLOOR = 3;
050    /**
051     * Constant for environment tiles that are walls near a cave. Value is 4.
052     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
053     */
054    public static final int CAVE_WALL = 4;
055    /**
056     * Constant for environment tiles that are floors for a corridor. Value is 5.
057     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
058     */
059    public static final int CORRIDOR_FLOOR = 5;
060    /**
061     * Constant for environment tiles that are walls near a corridor. Value is 6.
062     * Used by several classes that distinguish types of dungeon environment, like {@link SectionDungeonGenerator}.
063     */
064    public static final int CORRIDOR_WALL = 6;
065
066    public DungeonUtility() {
067        rng = new StatefulRNG();
068    }
069
070    public DungeonUtility(IStatefulRNG rng) {
071        this.rng = rng;
072    }
073
074    public DungeonUtility(IRNG rng) {
075        this.rng = new StatefulRNG(rng.nextLong());
076    }
077
078    /**
079     * The random number generator that will be used for all methods in this class with a random component.
080     */
081    public IStatefulRNG rng;
082    
083
084    /**
085     * Finds a random Coord where the x and y match up to a [x][y] location on map that has '.' as a value.
086     * Uses this class' rng field for pseudo-random number generation. May fail if there are very few floor tiles;
087     * use {@link #randomCell(short[])} given {@link #packedFloors(char[][])} to get a floor cell guaranteed if there is
088     * at least one, or better still, make a {@link GreasedRegion#GreasedRegion(char[][], char)} and get a single Coord
089     * from it with {@link GreasedRegion#singleRandom(IRNG)}. You can reuse a GreasedRegion with modifications, like
090     * removing cells you already picked, but using packedFloors() needs to make new short arrays each time. 
091     *
092     * @param map a char[][] that should contain a '.' floor tile
093     * @return a Coord that corresponds to a '.' in map, or null if a '.' cannot be found or if map is too small
094     */
095    public Coord randomFloor(char[][] map) {
096        int width = map.length;
097        int height = map[0].length;
098        if (width < 3 || height < 3)
099            return null;
100        int x = rng.nextInt(width - 2) + 1, y = rng.nextInt(height - 2) + 1;
101        for (int i = 0; i < 20; i++) {
102            if (map[x][y] == '.') {
103                return Coord.get(x, y);
104            } else {
105                x = rng.nextInt(width - 2) + 1;
106                y = rng.nextInt(height - 2) + 1;
107            }
108        }
109        x = 1;
110        y = 1;
111        if (map[x][y] == '.')
112            return Coord.get(x, y);
113
114        while (map[x][y] != '.') {
115            x += 1;
116            if (x >= width - 1) {
117                x = 1;
118                y += 1;
119            }
120            if (y >= height - 1)
121                return null;
122        }
123        return Coord.get(x, y);
124    }
125
126    /**
127     * Finds a random Coord where the x and y match up to a [x][y] location that is encoded as "on" in packed.
128     * This is useful when you have used {@code DungeonUtility.packedFloors(char[][] map)} to encode all floors in map,
129     * or {@code CoordPacker.pack(char[][] map, char... yes)} to encode all cells in a char[][] map that match a
130     * particular type, like '.' for floors or '~' for deep water, and want to efficiently get one randomly-chosen tile
131     * from it. Calling pack() is likely slightly less efficient than using randomFloor(), but it only needs to be done
132     * once per map and cell type, and this method should be substantially more efficient when the type of cell is
133     * uncommon on the map.
134     * Uses this class' rng field for pseudo-random number generation.
135     *
136     * @param packed a packed array produced by CoordPacker encoding the cells to choose from as "on"
137     * @return a Coord that corresponds to a '.' in map, or (-1, -1) if a '.' cannot be found or if map is too small
138     */
139    public Coord randomCell(short[] packed) {
140        CoordPacker.init();
141        return CoordPacker.singleRandom(packed, rng);
142    }
143
144    /**
145     * A convenience wrapper for getting a packed-data representation of all floors ('.') in map, for randomCell().
146     * If you want other chars or more chars than just the period, you can use CoordPacker.pack() with a char[][] map
147     * and one or more chars to find as the parameters. This is the same as calling {@code CoordPacker.pack(map, '.')}.
148     *
149     * @param map a char[][] that uses '.' to represent floors
150     * @return all floors in map in packed data format (a special short array) that can be given to randomCell()
151     */
152    public static short[] packedFloors(char[][] map) {
153        CoordPacker.init();
154        return CoordPacker.pack(map, '.');
155    }
156
157    /**
158     * Finds a random Coord where the x and y match up to a [x][y] location on map that has the same value as the
159     * parameter tile. Uses this class' rng field for pseudo-random number generation.
160     *
161     * @param map  a char[][] that should contain the desired tile
162     * @param tile the char to search for
163     * @return a Coord that corresponds to a map element equal to tile, or null if tile cannot be found or if map is too small.
164     */
165    public Coord randomMatchingTile(char[][] map, char tile) {
166        int width = map.length;
167        int height = map[0].length;
168        if (width < 3 || height < 3)
169            return null;
170        int x = rng.nextInt(width - 2) + 1, y = rng.nextInt(height - 2) + 1;
171        for (int i = 0; i < 30; i++) {
172            if (map[x][y] == tile) {
173                return Coord.get(x, y);
174            } else {
175                x = rng.nextInt(width - 2) + 1;
176                y = rng.nextInt(height - 2) + 1;
177            }
178        }
179        x = 1;
180        y = 1;
181        if (map[x][y] == tile)
182            return Coord.get(x, y);
183
184        while (map[x][y] != tile) {
185            x += 1;
186            if (x >= width - 1) {
187                x = 1;
188                y += 1;
189            }
190            if (y >= height - 1)
191                return null;
192        }
193        return Coord.get(x, y);
194    }
195
196    /**
197     * Gets a random Coord that is adjacent to start, validating whether the position can exist on the given map.
198     * Adjacency defaults to four-way cardinal directions unless eightWay is true, in which case it uses Chebyshev.
199     * This can step into walls, and should NOT be used for movement.  It is meant for things like sound that can
200     * exist in walls, or for assigning decor to floors or walls that are adjacent to floors.
201     *
202     * @param map      a char[][] map that this will only use for its width and height; contents are ignored
203     * @param start    the starting position
204     * @param eightWay true to choose a random orthogonal or diagonal direction; false to only choose from orthogonal
205     * @return a Coord that is adjacent to start on the map, or null if start is off the map or the map is very small
206     */
207    public Coord randomStep(char[][] map, Coord start, boolean eightWay) {
208        int width = map.length;
209        int height = map[0].length;
210        if (width < 3 || height < 3 || start.x < 0 || start.y < 0 || start.x > width - 1 || start.y > height - 1)
211            return null;
212        Coord stepped = Coord.get(start.x, start.y);
213
214        if (eightWay) {
215            int mv = rng.nextInt(9);
216            return Coord.get(Math.min(Math.max(0, stepped.x + (mv % 3) - 1), height - 1),
217                    Math.min(Math.max(0, stepped.y + (mv / 3) - 1), height - 1));
218        } else {
219            int mv = rng.nextInt(5);
220            switch (mv) {
221                case 0:
222                    return Coord.get(Math.min(Math.max(0, stepped.x - 1), height - 1),
223                            stepped.y);
224                case 1:
225                    return Coord.get(Math.min(Math.max(0, stepped.x + 1), height - 1),
226                            stepped.y);
227                case 2:
228                    return Coord.get(stepped.x,
229                            Math.min(Math.max(0, stepped.y - 1), height - 1));
230                case 3:
231                    return Coord.get(stepped.x,
232                            Math.min(Math.max(0, stepped.y + 1), height - 1));
233                default:
234                    return stepped;
235            }
236        }
237    }
238
239    /**
240     * Finds a random Coord where the x and y match up to a [x][y] location on map that has '.' as a value,
241     * and a square of cells extending in the positive x and y directions with a side length of size must also have
242     * '.' as their values.
243     * Uses this class' rng field for pseudo-random number generation.
244     *
245     * @param map  a char[][] that should contain at least one floor represented by '.'
246     * @param size the side length of a square that must be completely filled with floors for this to return it
247     * @return a Coord that corresponds to a '.' in map, or null if a '.' cannot be found or if map is too small.
248     */
249    public Coord randomFloorLarge(char[][] map, int size) {
250        int width = map.length;
251        int height = map[0].length;
252        if (width < size + 2 || height < size + 2)
253            return null;
254        int x = rng.nextInt(width - size), y = rng.nextInt(height - size);
255        CELL:
256        for (int i = 0; i < 20; i++, x = rng.nextInt(width - size), y = rng.nextInt(height - size)) {
257            if (map[x][y] == '.') {
258                for (int j = 0; j < size; j++) {
259                    for (int k = 0; k < size; k++) {
260                        if (map[x + j][y + k] != '.')
261                            continue CELL;
262                    }
263                }
264                return Coord.get(x, y);
265            }
266        }
267        x = 1;
268        y = 1;
269
270        SLOW:
271        while (true) {
272            x += 1;
273            if (x >= width - size) {
274                x = 1;
275                y += 1;
276            }
277            if (y >= height - size)
278                return null;
279            if (map[x][y] == '.') {
280                for (int j = 0; j < size; j++) {
281                    for (int k = 0; k < size; k++) {
282                        if (map[x + j][y + k] != '.')
283                            continue SLOW;
284                    }
285                }
286                return Coord.get(x, y);
287            }
288        }
289    }
290
291    /**
292     * Takes a char[][] dungeon map that uses '#' to represent walls, and returns a new char[][] that uses unicode box
293     * drawing characters to draw straight, continuous lines for walls, filling regions between walls (that were
294     * filled with more walls before) with space characters, ' '. If the lines "point the wrong way," such as having
295     * multiple horizontally adjacent vertical lines where there should be horizontal lines, call transposeLines() on
296     * the returned map, which will keep the dimensions of the map the same and only change the line chars. You will
297     * also need to call transposeLines if you call hashesToLines on a map that already has "correct" line-drawing
298     * characters, which means hashesToLines should only be called on maps that use '#' for walls. If you have a
299     * jumbled map that contains two or more of the following: "correct" line-drawing characters, "incorrect"
300     * line-drawing characters, and '#' characters for walls, you can reset by calling linesToHashes() and then
301     * potentially calling hashesToLines() again.
302     *
303     * @param map a 2D char array indexed with x,y that uses '#' for walls
304     * @return a copy of the map passed as an argument with box-drawing characters replacing '#' walls
305     */
306    public static char[][] hashesToLines(char[][] map) {
307        return hashesToLines(map, false);
308    }
309
310    private static final char[] wallLookup = new char[]
311            {
312                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '├', '─', '┘', '─', '┴', '┐', '┤', '┬', '┼',
313                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '├', '─', '┘', '─', '┴', '┐', '┤', '┬', '┼',
314                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '├', '─', '┘', '─', '┴', '┐', '┤', '┬', '┼',
315                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '│', '─', '┘', '─', '┴', '┐', '┤', '┬', '┤',
316                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '├', '─', '┘', '─', '┴', '┐', '┤', '┬', '┼',
317                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '├', '─', '┘', '─', '┴', '┐', '┤', '┬', '┼',
318                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '├', '─', '┘', '─', '┴', '┐', '┤', '─', '┴',
319                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '│', '─', '┘', '─', '┴', '┐', '┤', '─', '┘',
320                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '├', '─', '┘', '─', '┴', '┐', '┤', '┬', '┼',
321                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '├', '─', '┘', '─', '─', '┐', '┤', '┬', '┬',
322                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '├', '─', '┘', '─', '┴', '┐', '┤', '┬', '┼',
323                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '│', '─', '┘', '─', '─', '┐', '┤', '┬', '┐',
324                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '├', '─', '┘', '─', '┴', '┐', '│', '┬', '├',
325                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '├', '─', '┘', '─', '─', '┐', '│', '┬', '┌',
326                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '├', '─', '┘', '─', '┴', '┐', '│', '─', '└',
327                    '#', '│', '─', '└', '│', '│', '┌', '│', '─', '┘', '─', '─', '┐', '│', '─', '\1'
328            };
329
330    /**
331     * Takes a char[][] dungeon map that uses '#' to represent walls, and returns a new char[][] that uses unicode box
332     * drawing characters to draw straight, continuous lines for walls, filling regions between walls (that were
333     * filled with more walls before) with space characters, ' '. If keepSingleHashes is true, then '#' will be used if
334     * a wall has no orthogonal wall neighbors; if it is false, then a horizontal line will be used for stand-alone
335     * wall cells. If the lines "point the wrong way," such as having multiple horizontally adjacent vertical lines
336     * where there should be horizontal lines, call transposeLines() on the returned map, which will keep the dimensions
337     * of the map the same and only change the line chars. You will also need to call transposeLines if you call
338     * hashesToLines on a map that already has "correct" line-drawing characters, which means hashesToLines should only
339     * be called on maps that use '#' for walls. If you have a jumbled map that contains two or more of the following:
340     * "correct" line-drawing characters, "incorrect" line-drawing characters, and '#' characters for walls, you can
341     * reset by calling linesToHashes() and then potentially calling hashesToLines() again.
342     *
343     * @param map              a 2D char array indexed with x,y that uses '#' for walls
344     * @param keepSingleHashes true if walls that are not orthogonally adjacent to other walls should stay as '#'
345     * @return a copy of the map passed as an argument with box-drawing characters replacing '#' walls
346     */
347    public static char[][] hashesToLines(char[][] map, boolean keepSingleHashes) {
348        int width = map.length + 2;
349        int height = map[0].length + 2;
350
351        char[][] dungeon = new char[width][height];
352        for (int i = 1; i < width - 1; i++) {
353            System.arraycopy(map[i - 1], 0, dungeon[i], 1, height - 2);
354        }
355        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
356            dungeon[i][0] = '\1';
357            dungeon[i][height - 1] = '\1';
358        }
359        for (int i = 0; i < height; i++) {
360            dungeon[0][i] = '\1';
361            dungeon[width - 1][i] = '\1';
362        }
363        for (int x = 1; x < width - 1; x++) {
364            for (int y = 1; y < height - 1; y++) {
365                if (map[x - 1][y - 1] == '#') {
366                    int q = 0;
367                    q |= (y <= 1 || map[x - 1][y - 2] == '#' || map[x - 1][y - 2] == '+' || map[x - 1][y - 2] == '/') ? 1 : 0;
368                    q |= (x >= width - 2 || map[x][y - 1] == '#' || map[x][y - 1] == '+' || map[x][y - 1] == '/') ? 2 : 0;
369                    q |= (y >= height - 2 || map[x - 1][y] == '#' || map[x - 1][y] == '+' || map[x - 1][y] == '/') ? 4 : 0;
370                    q |= (x <= 1 || map[x - 2][y - 1] == '#' || map[x - 2][y - 1] == '+' || map[x - 2][y - 1] == '/') ? 8 : 0;
371
372                    q |= (y <= 1 || x >= width - 2 || map[x][y - 2] == '#' || map[x][y - 2] == '+' || map[x][y - 2] == '/') ? 16 : 0;
373                    q |= (y >= height - 2 || x >= width - 2 || map[x][y] == '#' || map[x][y] == '+' || map[x][y] == '/') ? 32 : 0;
374                    q |= (y >= height - 2 || x <= 1 || map[x - 2][y] == '#' || map[x - 2][y] == '+' || map[x - 2][y] == '/') ? 64 : 0;
375                    q |= (y <= 1 || x <= 1 || map[x - 2][y - 2] == '#' || map[x - 2][y - 2] == '+' || map[x - 2][y - 2] == '/') ? 128 : 0;
376                    if (!keepSingleHashes && wallLookup[q] == '#') {
377                        dungeon[x][y] = '─';
378                    } else {
379                        dungeon[x][y] = wallLookup[q];
380                    }
381                }
382            }
383        }
384        char[][] portion = new char[width - 2][height - 2];
385        for (int i = 1; i < width - 1; i++) {
386            for (int j = 1; j < height - 1; j++) {
387                switch (dungeon[i][j]) {
388                    case '\1':
389                        portion[i - 1][j - 1] = ' ';
390                        break;
391                    default: // ┼┌┘
392                        portion[i - 1][j - 1] = dungeon[i][j];
393                }
394            }
395        }
396        return portion;
397    }
398
399    /**
400     * Reverses most of the effects of hashesToLines(). The only things that will not be reversed are the placement of
401     * space characters in unreachable wall-cells-behind-wall-cells, which remain as spaces. This is useful if you
402     * have a modified map that contains wall characters of conflicting varieties, as described in hashesToLines().
403     *
404     * @param map a 2D char array indexed with x,y that uses box-drawing characters for walls
405     * @return a copy of the map passed as an argument with '#' replacing box-drawing characters for walls
406     */
407    public static char[][] linesToHashes(char[][] map) {
408
409        int width = map.length;
410        int height = map[0].length;
411        char[][] portion = new char[width][height];
412        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
413            for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
414                switch (map[i][j]) {
415                    case '\1':
416                    case '├':
417                    case '┤':
418                    case '┴':
419                    case '┬':
420                    case '┌':
421                    case '┐':
422                    case '└':
423                    case '┘':
424                    case '│':
425                    case '─':
426                    case '┼':
427                        portion[i][j] = '#';
428                        break;
429                    default:
430                        portion[i][j] = map[i][j];
431                }
432            }
433        }
434        return portion;
435    }
436
437    /**
438     * If you call hashesToLines() on a map that uses [y][x] conventions instead of [x][y], it will have the lines not
439     * connect as you expect. Use this function to change the directions of the box-drawing characters only, without
440     * altering the dimensions in any way. This returns a new char[][], instead of modifying the parameter in place.
441     * transposeLines is also needed if the lines in a map have become transposed when they were already correct;
442     * calling this method on an incorrectly transposed map will change the directions on all of its lines.
443     *
444     * @param map a 2D char array indexed with y,x that uses box-drawing characters for walls
445     * @return a copy of map that uses box-drawing characters for walls that will be correct when indexed with x,y
446     */
447    public static char[][] transposeLines(char[][] map) {
448
449        int width = map[0].length;
450        int height = map.length;
451        char[][] portion = new char[height][width];
452        for (int i = 0; i < height; i++) {
453            for (int j = 0; j < width; j++) {
454                switch (map[i][j]) {
455                    case '\1':
456                        portion[i][j] = ' ';
457                        break;
458                    case '├':
459                        portion[i][j] = '┬';
460                        break;
461                    case '┤':
462                        portion[i][j] = '┴';
463                        break;
464                    case '┴':
465                        portion[i][j] = '┤';
466                        break;
467                    case '┬':
468                        portion[i][j] = '├';
469                        break;
470                    case '┐':
471                        portion[i][j] = '└';
472                        break;
473                    case '└':
474                        portion[i][j] = '┐';
475                        break;
476                    case '│':
477                        portion[i][j] = '─';
478                        break;
479                    case '─':
480                        portion[i][j] = '│';
481                        break;
482                    default: //applies to ┼┌┘ and any non-box-drawing
483                        portion[i][j] = map[i][j];
484                }
485            }
486        }
487        return portion;
488    }
489    //                    case '├ ┤ ┴ ┬ ┌ ┐ └ ┘ │ ─':
490    /**
491     * When a map is generated by DungeonGenerator with addDoors enabled, different chars are used for vertical and
492     * horizontal doors ('+' for vertical and '/' for horizontal).  This makes all doors '+', which is useful if you
493     * want '/' to be used for a different purpose and/or to distinguish open and closed doors.
494     *
495     * @param map a char[][] that may have both '+' and '/' for doors
496     * @return a char[][] that only uses '+' for all doors
497     */
498    public static char[][] closeDoors(char[][] map) {
499
500        int width = map.length;
501        int height = map[0].length;
502        char[][] portion = new char[width][height];
503        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
504            for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
505                if (map[i][j] == '/') portion[i][j] = '+';
506                else portion[i][j] = map[i][j];
507
508            }
509        }
510        return portion;
511    }
512
513    /**
514     * When a map is generated by DungeonGenerator with addDoors enabled, different chars are used for vertical and
515     * horizontal doors ('+' for vertical and '/' for horizontal).  This makes all doors '/', which is useful if you
516     * want '+' to be used for a different purpose and/or to distinguish open and closed doors.
517     *
518     * @param map a char[][] that may have both '+' and '/' for doors
519     * @return a char[][] that only uses '/' for all doors
520     */
521    public static char[][] openDoors(char[][] map) {
522
523        int width = map.length;
524        int height = map[0].length;
525        char[][] portion = new char[width][height];
526        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
527            for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
528                if (map[i][j] == '+') portion[i][j] = '/';
529                else portion[i][j] = map[i][j];
530            }
531        }
532        return portion;
533    }
534
535
536    /**
537     * Takes a char[][] dungeon map and returns a copy with all box drawing chars, special placeholder chars, or '#'
538     * chars changed to '#' and everything else changed to '.' .
539     *
540     * @param map a char[][] with different characters that can be simplified to "wall" or "floor"
541     * @return a copy of map with all box-drawing, placeholder, wall or space characters as '#' and everything else '.'
542     */
543    public static char[][] simplifyDungeon(char[][] map) {
544
545        int width = map.length;
546        int height = map[0].length;
547        char[][] portion = new char[width][height];
548        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
549            for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
550                switch (map[i][j]) {
551                    case '\1':
552                    case '├':
553                    case '┤':
554                    case '┴':
555                    case '┬':
556                    case '┌':
557                    case '┐':
558                    case '└':
559                    case '┘':
560                    case '│':
561                    case '─':
562                    case '┼':
563                    case ' ':
564                    case '#':
565                        portion[i][j] = '#';
566                        break;
567                    default:
568                        portion[i][j] = '.';
569                }
570            }
571        }
572        return portion;
573    }
574
575    /**
576     * Takes a dungeon map with either '#' as the only wall character or the unicode box drawing characters used by
577     * hashesToLines(), and returns a new char[][] dungeon map with two characters per cell, mostly filling the spaces
578     * next to non-walls with space characters, and only doing anything different if a box-drawing character would
579     * continue into an adjacent cell, or if a '#' wall needs another '#' wall next to it. The recommended approach is
580     * to keep both the original non-double-width map and the newly-returned double-width map, since the single-width
581     * maps can be used more easily for pathfinding. If you need to undo this function, call unDoubleWidth().
582     *
583     * @param map a char[][] that uses either '#' or box-drawing characters for walls, but one per cell
584     * @return a widened copy of map that uses two characters for every cell, connecting box-drawing chars correctly
585     */
586    public static char[][] doubleWidth(char[][] map) {
587        int width = map.length;
588        int height = map[0].length;
589        char[][] paired = new char[width * 2][height];
590        for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
591            for (int x = 0, px = 0; x < width; x++, px += 2) {
592                paired[px][y] = map[x][y];
593                switch (paired[px][y]) {
594                    //                        case '┼ ├ ┤ ┴ ┬ ┌ ┐ └ ┘ │ ─'
595                    case '┼':
596                    case '├':
597                    case '┴':
598                    case '┬':
599                    case '┌':
600                    case '└':
601                    case '─':
602                        paired[px + 1][y] = '─';
603                        break;
604                    case '#':
605                        paired[px + 1][y] = '#';
606                        break;
607
608                    default:
609                        paired[px + 1][y] = ' ';
610                        break;
611                        /*
612                    case '.':
613                    case '┤':
614                    case '┐':
615                    case '┘':
616                    case '│':
617                         */
618                }
619            }
620        }
621        return paired;
622    }
623
624    /**
625     * Takes a dungeon map that uses two characters per cell, and condenses it to use only the left (lower index)
626     * character in each cell. This should (probably) only be called on the result of doubleWidth(), and will throw an
627     * exception if called on a map with an odd number of characters for width, such as "#...#" .
628     *
629     * @param map a char[][] that has been widened by doubleWidth()
630     * @return a copy of map that uses only one char per cell
631     */
632    public static char[][] unDoubleWidth(char[][] map) {
633        int width = map.length;
634        int height = map[0].length;
635        if (width % 2 != 0)
636            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Argument must be a char[width][height] with an even width.");
637        char[][] unpaired = new char[width / 2][height];
638        for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
639            for (int x = 0, px = 0; px < width; x++, px += 2) {
640                unpaired[x][y] = map[px][y];
641            }
642        }
643        return unpaired;
644    }
645
646
647    /**
648     * Given a char[][] for the map, produces a double[][] that can be used with FOV.calculateFOV(). It expects any
649     * doors to be represented by '+' if closed or '/' if open (which can be caused by calling
650     * DungeonUtility.closeDoors() ), any walls to be '#' or box drawing characters, and it doesn't care what other
651     * chars are used (only doors, including open ones, and walls obscure light and thus have a resistance by default).
652     * <br>
653     * This is here for backwards-compatibility; this method delegates to {@link FOV#generateResistances(char[][])}.
654     *
655     * @param map a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors()
656     * @return a resistance map suitable for use with the FOV class, with clear cells assigned 0.0 and blocked ones 1.0
657     */
658    public static double[][] generateResistances(char[][] map) {
659        return FOV.generateResistances(map);
660    }
661
662    /**
663     * Given a char[][] for the map that should use box drawing characters (as produced by
664     * {@link #hashesToLines(char[][], boolean)}), produces a double[][] with triple width and triple height that can be
665     * used with FOV.calculateFOV() in classes that use subcell lighting. Importantly, this only considers a "thin line"
666     * of wall to be blocking (matching the box drawing character), instead of the whole 3x3 area. This expects any
667     * doors to be represented by '+' if closed or '/' if open (which can be caused by calling
668     * {@link #closeDoors(char[][])}), thick vegetation or other concealing obstructions to be '"', any normal walls to
669     * be box drawing characters, any cells that block all subcells to be '#', and it doesn't care what other chars are
670     * used (only doors, including open ones, vegetation, and walls obscure light and thus have a resistance normally).
671     * <br>
672     * This is here for backwards-compatibility; this method delegates to {@link FOV#generateResistances3x3(char[][])}
673     * 
674     * @param map a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors()
675     * @return a resistance map suitable for use with the FOV class and subcell lighting, with triple width/height
676     */
677    public static double[][] generateResistances3x3(char[][] map) {
678        return FOV.generateResistances3x3(map);
679    }
680
681    /**
682     * Given a char[][] for the map, produces a double[][] that can be used with FOV.calculateFOV(), but does not treat
683     * any cells as partly transparent, only fully-blocking or fully-permitting light. This is mainly useful if you
684     * expect the FOV radius to be very high or (effectively) infinite, since anything less than complete blockage would
685     * be passed through by infinite-radius FOV. This expects any doors to be represented by '+' if closed or '/' if
686     * open (most door placement defaults to a mix of '+' and '/', so by calling
687     * {@link DungeonUtility#closeDoors(char[][])} you can close all doors at the start), and any walls to be '#' or
688     * box drawing characters. This will assign 1.0 resistance to walls and closed doors or 0.0 for any other cell.
689     * <br>
690     * This is here for backwards-compatibility; this method delegates to {@link FOV#generateSimpleResistances(char[][])}.
691     *
692     * @param map a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors()
693     * @return a resistance map suitable for use with the FOV class, but with no partially transparent cells
694     */
695    public static double[][] generateSimpleResistances(char[][] map) {
696        return FOV.generateSimpleResistances(map);
697    }
698
699    /**
700     * Given a char[][] for the map that should use box drawing characters (as produced by
701     * {@link #hashesToLines(char[][], boolean)}), produces a double[][] with triple width and triple height that can be
702     * used with FOV.calculateFOV() in classes that use subcell lighting. This expects any doors to be represented by
703     * '+' if closed or '/' if open (most door placement defaults to a mix of '+' and '/', so by calling
704     * {@link DungeonUtility#closeDoors(char[][])} you can close all doors at the start), any walls to be box drawing
705     * characters, and any cells that block all subcells within their area to be '#'. This will assign 1.0 resistance to
706     * walls and closed doors where a line of the box drawing char would block light, or 0.0 for any other subcell.
707     * <br>
708     * This is here for backwards-compatibility; this method delegates to {@link FOV#generateSimpleResistances3x3(char[][])}.
709     *
710     * @param map a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors()
711     * @return a resistance map suitable for use with the FOV class and subcell lighting, with triple width/height
712     */
713    public static double[][] generateSimpleResistances3x3(char[][] map) {
714        return FOV.generateSimpleResistances3x3(map);
715    }
716
717    /**
718     * Given a char[][] for the map, a Map of Character keys to Double values that will be used to determine costs, and
719     * a double value for unhandled characters, produces a double[][] that can be used as a costMap by DijkstraMap. It
720     * expects any doors to be represented by '+' if closed or '/' if open (which can be caused by calling
721     * DungeonUtility.closeDoors() ) and any walls to be '#' or box drawing characters. In the parameter costs, there
722     * does not need to be an entry for '#' or any box drawing characters, but if one is present for '#' it will apply
723     * that cost to both '#' and all box drawing characters, and if one is not present it will default to a very high
724     * number. For any other entry in costs, a char in the 2D char array that matches the key will correspond
725     * (at the same x,y position in the returned 2D double array) to that key's value in costs. If a char is used in the
726     * map but does not have a corresponding key in costs, it will be given the value of the parameter defaultValue.
727     * <p/>
728     * The values in costs are multipliers, so should not be negative, should only be 0.0 in cases where you want
729     * infinite movement across all adjacent squares of that kind, should be higher than 1.0 for difficult terrain (2.0
730     * and 3.0 are reasonable), should be between 0.0 and 1.0 for easy terrain, and should be 1.0 for normal terrain.
731     * If a cell should not be possible to enter for this character, 999.0 should be a reasonable value for a cost.
732     * <p/>
733     * An example use for this would be to make a creature unable to enter any non-water cell (like a fish),
734     * unable to enter doorways (like some mythological versions of vampires), or to make a wheeled vehicle take more
735     * time to move across rubble or rough terrain.
736     * <p/>
737     * A potentially common case that needs to be addressed is NPC movement onto staircases in games that have them;
738     * some games may find it desirable for NPCs to block staircases and others may not, but in either case you should
739     * give both '&gt;' and '&lt;', the standard characters for staircases, the same value in costs.
740     *
741     * @param map          a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors() .
742     * @param costs        a Map of Character keys representing possible elements in map, and Double values for their cost.
743     * @param defaultValue a double that will be used as the cost for any characters that don't have a key in costs.
744     * @return a cost map suitable for use with DijkstraMap
745     */
746    public static double[][] generateCostMap(char[][] map, Map<Character, Double> costs, double defaultValue) {
747        int width = map.length;
748        int height = map[0].length;
749        double[][] portion = new double[width][height];
750        char current;
751        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
752            for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
753                current = map[i][j];
754                if (costs.containsKey(current)) {
755                    portion[i][j] = costs.get(current);
756                } else {
757                    switch (current) {
758                        case '\1':
759                        case '├':
760                        case '┤':
761                        case '┴':
762                        case '┬':
763                        case '┌':
764                        case '┐':
765                        case '└':
766                        case '┘':
767                        case '│':
768                        case '─':
769                        case '┼':
770                        case '#':
771                            portion[i][j] = (costs.containsKey('#'))
772                                    ? costs.get('#')
773                                    : squidpony.squidai.DijkstraMap.WALL;
774                            break;
775                        default:
776                            portion[i][j] = defaultValue;
777                    }
778                }
779            }
780        }
781        return portion;
782    }
783
784    /**
785     * Given a char[][] for the map, produces a double[][] that can be used as a map by AStarSearch. It
786     * expects any doors to be represented by '+' if closed or '/' if open (which can be ensured by calling
787     * {@link #closeDoors(char[][])}) and any walls to be '#' or box drawing characters. Any wall or closed door will be
788     * assigned a negative number, meaning it is impassable for AStarSearch, and all other chars will be assigned 1.0,
789     * giving them a normal cost.
790     *
791     * @param map          a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors() .
792     * @return a cost map suitable for use with AStarSearch
793     */
794    public static double[][] generateAStarCostMap(char[][] map) {
795        int width = map.length;
796        int height = map[0].length;
797        double[][] portion = new double[width][height];
798        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
799            for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
800                switch (map[i][j]) {
801                    case '\1':
802                    case '├':
803                    case '┤':
804                    case '┴':
805                    case '┬':
806                    case '┌':
807                    case '┐':
808                    case '└':
809                    case '┘':
810                    case '│':
811                    case '─':
812                    case '┼':
813                    case '#':
814                    case '+':
815                        portion[i][j] = -1;
816                        break;
817                    default:
818                        portion[i][j] = 1;
819                }
820            }
821        }
822        return portion;
823    }
824
825    /**
826     * Given a char[][] for the map, a Map of Character keys to Double values that will be used to determine costs, and
827     * a double value for unhandled characters, produces a double[][] that can be used as a map by AStarSearch. It
828     * expects any doors to be represented by '+' if closed or '/' if open (which can be caused by calling
829     * DungeonUtility.closeDoors() ) and any walls to be '#' or box drawing characters. In the parameter costs, there
830     * does not need to be an entry for '#' or any box drawing characters, but if one is present for '#' it will apply
831     * that cost to both '#' and all box drawing characters, and if one is not present it will default to a negative
832     * number, meaning it is impassable for AStarSearch. For any other entry in costs, a char in the 2D char array that
833     * matches the key will correspond (at the same x,y position in the returned 2D double array) to that key's value in
834     * costs. If a char is used in the map but does not have a corresponding key in costs, it will be given the value of
835     * the parameter defaultValue, which is typically 1 unless a creature is limited to only moving in some terrain.
836     * <p/>
837     * The values in costs are different from those expected for DijkstraMap; negative numbers are impassable, 1 is the
838     * cost for a normal walkable tile, and higher numbers are harder to enter.
839     * <p/>
840     * An example use for this would be to make a creature unable to enter any non-water cell (like a fish),
841     * unable to enter doorways (like some mythological versions of vampires), or to make a wheeled vehicle take more
842     * time to move across rubble or rough terrain.
843     * <p/>
844     * A potentially common case that needs to be addressed is NPC movement onto staircases in games that have them;
845     * some games may find it desirable for NPCs to block staircases and others may not, but in either case you should
846     * give both '&gt;' and '&lt;', the standard characters for staircases, the same value in costs.
847     *
848     * @param map          a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors() .
849     * @param costs        a Map of Character keys representing possible elements in map, and Double values for their cost.
850     * @param defaultValue a double that will be used as the cost for any characters that don't have a key in costs.
851     * @return a cost map suitable for use with AStarSearch
852     */
853    public static double[][] generateAStarCostMap(char[][] map, Map<Character, Double> costs, double defaultValue) {
854        int width = map.length;
855        int height = map[0].length;
856        double[][] portion = new double[width][height];
857        char current;
858        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
859            for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
860                current = map[i][j];
861                if (costs.containsKey(current)) {
862                    portion[i][j] = costs.get(current);
863                } else {
864                    switch (current) {
865                        case '\1':
866                        case '├':
867                        case '┤':
868                        case '┴':
869                        case '┬':
870                        case '┌':
871                        case '┐':
872                        case '└':
873                        case '┘':
874                        case '│':
875                        case '─':
876                        case '┼':
877                        case '#':
878                            portion[i][j] = (costs.containsKey('#'))
879                                    ? costs.get('#')
880                                    : -1;
881                            break;
882                        default:
883                            portion[i][j] = defaultValue;
884                    }
885                }
886            }
887        }
888        return portion;
889    }
890
891    public static double[][] translateAStarToDijkstra(double[][] astar) {
892        if (astar == null) return null;
893        if (astar.length <= 0 || astar[0].length <= 0)
894            return new double[0][0];
895        double[][] dijkstra = new double[astar.length][astar[0].length];
896        for (int x = 0; x < astar.length; x++) {
897            for (int y = 0; y < astar[x].length; y++) {
898                if (astar[x][y] <= 0)
899                    dijkstra[x][y] = DijkstraMap.WALL;
900                else
901                    dijkstra[x][y] = DijkstraMap.FLOOR;
902            }
903        }
904        return dijkstra;
905    }
906
907    public static double[][] translateDijkstraToAStar(double[][] dijkstra) {
908        if (dijkstra == null) return null;
909        if (dijkstra.length <= 0 || dijkstra[0].length <= 0)
910            return new double[0][0];
911        double[][] astar = new double[dijkstra.length][dijkstra[0].length];
912        for (int x = 0; x < dijkstra.length; x++) {
913            for (int y = 0; y < dijkstra[x].length; y++) {
914                if (dijkstra[x][y] >  DijkstraMap.FLOOR)
915                    astar[x][y] = -1;
916                else
917                    astar[x][y] = 1;
918            }
919        }
920        return astar;
921    }
922
923    /**
924     * @param rng
925     * @param map
926     * @param acceptable
927     * @param frustration The number of trials that this method can do. Usually 16 or
928     *                    32.
929     * @return A random cell in {@code map} whose symbol is in
930     * {@code acceptable}. Or {@code null} if not found.
931     */
932    public static /* @Nullable */Coord getRandomCell(IRNG rng, char[][] map, Set<Character> acceptable,
933                                                     int frustration) {
934        if (frustration < 0)
935            throw new IllegalStateException("Frustration should not be negative");
936        final int width = map.length;
937        final int height = width == 0 ? 0 : map[0].length;
938        if (width == 0 || height == 0)
939            throw new IllegalStateException("Map must be non-empty to get a cell from it");
940        int i = 0;
941        while (i < frustration) {
942            final int x = rng.nextInt(width);
943            final int y = rng.nextInt(height);
944            if (acceptable.contains(map[x][y]))
945                return Coord.get(x, y);
946            i++;
947        }
948        return null;
949    }
950
951    /**
952     * @param level dungeon/map level as 2D char array. x,y indexed
953     * @param c     Coord to check
954     * @return {@code true} if {@code c} is valid in {@code level}, {@code false} otherwise.
955     */
956    public static boolean inLevel(char[][] level, Coord c) {
957        return inLevel(level, c.x, c.y);
958    }
959
960    /**
961     * @param level dungeon/map level as 2D char array. x,y indexed
962     * @param x     x coordinate to check
963     * @param y     y coordinate to check
964     * @return {@code true} if {@code c} is valid in {@code level}, {@code false} otherwise.
965     */
966    public static boolean inLevel(char[][] level, int x, int y) {
967        return 0 <= x && x < level.length && 0 <= y && y < level[x].length;
968    }

970    /**
971     * @param level dungeon/map level as 2D double array. x,y indexed
972     * @param c     Coord to check
973     * @return {@code true} if {@code c} is valid in {@code level}, {@code false} otherwise.
974     */
975    public static boolean inLevel(double[][] level, Coord c) {
976        return inLevel(level, c.x, c.y);
977    }

979    /**
980     * @param level dungeon/map level as 2D double array. x,y indexed
981     * @param x     x coordinate to check
982     * @param y     y coordinate to check
983     * @return {@code true} if {@code c} is valid in {@code level}, {@code false} otherwise.
984     */
985    public static boolean inLevel(double[][] level, int x, int y) {
986        return 0 <= x && x < level.length && 0 <= y && y < level[x].length;
987    }

989    /**
990     * @param level a dungeon/map level as 2D array. x,y indexed
991     * @param c     Coord to check
992     * @return {@code true} if {@code c} is valid in {@code level}, {@code false} otherwise.
993     */
994    public static <T> boolean inLevel(T[][] level, Coord c) {
995        return inLevel(level, c.x, c.y);
996    }

998    /**
999     * @param level a dungeon/map level as 2D array. x,y indexed
1000     * @param x     x coordinate to check
1001     * @param y     y coordinate to check
1002     * @return {@code true} if {@code c} is valid in {@code level}, {@code false} otherwise.
1003     */
1004    public static <T> boolean inLevel(T[][] level, int x, int y) {
1005        return 0 <= x && x < level.length && 0 <= y && y < level[x].length;
1006    }
1007    
1008    /**
1009     * Quickly counts the number of char elements in level that are equal to match.
1010     *
1011     * @param level the 2D char array to count cells in
1012     * @param match the char to search for
1013     * @return the number of cells that matched
1014     */
1015    public static int countCells(char[][] level, char match) {
1016        if (level == null || level.length == 0)
1017            return 0;
1018        int counter = 0;
1019        for (int x = 0; x < level.length; x++) {
1020            for (int y = 0; y < level[x].length; y++) {
1021                if (level[x][y] == match) counter++;
1022            }
1023        }
1024        return counter;
1025    }
1026
1027    /**
1028     * For when you want to print a 2D char array. Prints on multiple lines, with a trailing newline.
1029     *
1030     * @param level a 2D char array to print with a trailing newline
1031     */
1032    public static void debugPrint(char[][] level) {
1033        if (level == null || level.length == 0 || level[0].length == 0)
1034            System.out.println("INVALID DUNGEON LEVEL");
1035        else {
1036            for (int y = 0; y < level[0].length; y++) {
1037                for (int x = 0; x < level.length; x++) {
1038                    System.out.print(level[x][y]);
1039                }
1040                System.out.println();
1041
1042            }
1043        }
1044    }
1045
1046    /**
1047     * Changes the outer edge of a char[][] to the wall char, '#'.
1048     *
1049     * @param map A char[][] that stores map data; will be modified in place
1050     * @return the modified-in-place map with its edge replaced with '#'
1051     */
1052    public static char[][] wallWrap(char[][] map) {
1053        int upperY = map[0].length - 1;
1054        int upperX = map.length - 1;
1055        for (int i = 0; i < map.length; i++) {
1056            map[i][0] = '#';
1057            map[i][upperY] = '#';
1058        }
1059        for (int i = 0; i < map[0].length; i++) {
1060            map[0][i] = '#';
1061            map[upperX][i] = '#';
1062        }
1063        return map;
1064    }
1065    public static ArrayList<Coord> pointPath(int width, int height, IRNG rng) {
1066        if (width <= 2 || height <= 2)
1067            throw new IllegalArgumentException("width and height must be greater than 2");
1068        CoordPacker.init();
1069        long columnAlterations = (rng.nextLong() & 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFL);
1070        float columnBase = width / (Long.bitCount(columnAlterations) + 48.0f);
1071        long rowAlterations = (rng.nextLong() & 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFL);
1072        float rowBase = height / (Long.bitCount(rowAlterations) + 48.0f);
1073
1074        int[] columns = new int[16], rows = new int[16];
1075        int csum = 0, rsum = 0;
1076        long b = 7;
1077        for (int i = 0; i < 16; i++, b <<= 3) {
1078            columns[i] = csum + (int) (columnBase * 0.5f * (3 + Long.bitCount(columnAlterations & b)));
1079            csum += (int) (columnBase * (3 + Long.bitCount(columnAlterations & b)));
1080            rows[i] = rsum + (int) (rowBase * 0.5f * (3 + Long.bitCount(rowAlterations & b)));
1081            rsum += (int) (rowBase * (3 + Long.bitCount(rowAlterations & b)));
1082        }
1083        int cs = width - csum;
1084        int rs = height - rsum;
1085        int cs2 = cs, rs2 = rs, cs3 = cs, rs3 = rs;
1086        for (int i = 0; i <= 7; i++) {
1087            cs2 = cs2 * i / 7;
1088            rs2 = rs2 * i / 7;
1089            columns[i] -= cs2;
1090            rows[i] -= rs2;
1091        }
1092        for (int i = 15; i >= 8; i--) {
1093            cs3 = cs3 * (i - 8) >> 3;
1094            rs3 = rs3 * (i - 8) >> 3;
1095            columns[i] += cs3;
1096            rows[i] += rs3;
1097        }
1098
1099        ArrayList<Coord> points = new ArrayList<>(80);
1100        int m = rng.nextInt(64);
1101        Coord temp = CoordPacker.mooreToCoord(m), next;
1102        temp = Coord.get(columns[temp.x], rows[temp.y]);
1103        for (int i = 0, r; i < 256; r = rng.between(4, 12), i += r, m += r) {
1104            next = CoordPacker.mooreToCoord(m);
1105            next = Coord.get(columns[next.x], rows[next.y]);
1106            points.addAll(OrthoLine.line(temp, next));
1107            temp = next;
1108        }
1109        points.add(points.get(0));
1110        return points;
1111    }
1112
1113    /**
1114     * Ensures a path exists in a rough ring around the map by first creating the path (using
1115     * {@link #pointPath(int, int, IRNG)} with the given IRNG), then finding chars in blocking that are on that path and
1116     * replacing them with replacement. Modifies map in-place (!) and returns an ArrayList of Coord points that will
1117     * always be on the path.
1118     *
1119     * @param map         a 2D char array, x then y, etc. that will be modified directly; this is the "returned map"
1120     * @param rng         used for random factors in the path choice
1121     * @param replacement the char that will fill be used where a path needs to be carved out; usually '.'
1122     * @param blocking    an array or vararg of char that are considered blocking for the path and will be replaced if
1123     *                    they are in the way
1124     * @return the ArrayList of Coord points that are on the carved path, including existing non-blocking cells; will be empty if any parameters are invalid
1125     */
1126    public static ArrayList<Coord> ensurePath(char[][] map, IRNG rng, char replacement, char... blocking) {
1127        if (map == null || map.length <= 0 || blocking == null || blocking.length <= 0)
1128            return new ArrayList<Coord>(0);
1129        int width = map.length, height = map[0].length;
1130        ArrayList<Coord> points = pointPath(width, height, rng);
1131        char[] blocks = new char[blocking.length];
1132        System.arraycopy(blocking, 0, blocks, 0, blocking.length);
1133        Arrays.sort(blocks);
1134        for (Coord c : points) {
1135            if (c.x >= 0 && c.x < width && c.y >= 0 && c.y < height && Arrays.binarySearch(blocks, map[c.x][c.y]) >= 0) {
1136                map[c.x][c.y] = replacement;
1137            }
1138        }
1139        return points;
1140    }
1141
1142    public static ArrayList<Coord> allMatching(char[][] map, char... matching) {
1143        if (map == null || map.length <= 0 || matching == null || matching.length <= 0)
1144            return new ArrayList<Coord>(0);
1145        int width = map.length, height = map[0].length;
1146        char[] matches = new char[matching.length];
1147        System.arraycopy(matching, 0, matches, 0, matching.length);
1148        Arrays.sort(matches);
1149        ArrayList<Coord> points = new ArrayList<Coord>(map.length * 4);
1150        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1151            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
1152                if (Arrays.binarySearch(matches, map[x][y]) >= 0)
1153                    points.add(Coord.get(x, y));
1154            }
1155        }
1156        return points;
1157    }
1158
1159    /**
1160     * Gets a List of Coord that are within radius distance of (x,y), and appends them to buf if it is non-null or makes
1161     * a fresh List to append to otherwise. Returns buf if non-null, else the fresh List of Coord. May produce Coord
1162     * values that are not within the boundaries of a map, such as (-5,-4), if the center is too close to the edge or
1163     * radius is too high. You can use {@link squidpony.squidgrid.Radius#inCircle(int, int, int, boolean, int, int, List)}
1164     * with surpassEdges as false if you want to limit Coords to within the map, or the more general
1165     * {@link squidpony.squidgrid.Radius#pointsInside(int, int, int, boolean, int, int, List)} on a Radius.SQUARE or
1166     * Radius.DIAMOND enum value if you want a square or diamond shape.
1167     *
1168     * @param x      center x of the circle
1169     * @param y      center y of the circle
1170     * @param radius inclusive radius to extend from the center; radius 0 gives just the center
1171     * @param buf    Where to add the coordinates, or null for this method to
1172     *               allocate a fresh list.
1173     * @return The coordinates of a circle centered {@code (x, y)}, whose
1174     * diameter is {@code (radius * 2) + 1}.
1175     * @see squidpony.squidgrid.Radius#inCircle(int, int, int, boolean, int, int, List) if you want to keep the Coords within the bounds of the map
1176     */
1177    public static List<Coord> circle(int x, int y, int radius, /* @Nullable */ List<Coord> buf) {
1178        final List<Coord> result = buf == null ? new ArrayList<Coord>() : buf;
1179        radius = Math.max(0, radius);
1180        for (int dx = -radius; dx <= radius; ++dx) {
1181            final int high = (int) Math.floor(Math.sqrt(radius * radius - dx * dx));
1182            for (int dy = -high; dy <= high; ++dy) {
1183                result.add(Coord.get(x + dx, y + dy));
1184            }
1185        }
1186        return result;
1187    }
1188}
